comments.commentBody: Surely you don't think the point of this article is to make the South look good?

You could find similar sentiments expressed by United States soldiers to those expressed above by confederate traitors. Soldiers on both sides, loyal and disloyal,  prayed to the same God and believed he supported their cause. The idea that southern soldiers were uniquely religious is just more confederate propaganda.
I agree with you except I would argue that it it not that we have put our faith in the free market, but that we have been lied to about the nature of markets.

I agree.

All of capitalism's economic theories are based on a non-corrupted marketplace. LIBOR defines the cost of capital. If LIBOR is controlled by back-room deals we no longer have market capitalism but a form of subversive capitalism which mitigates contracts, tariffs, etc.

The invisible hand has become delusional.

Meredith,

'The irony is that Glass Steagall is really a conservative idea, since its firewall prudently preserves a sensible balanced system that protects the resources of millions—these words are all the traditional buzzwords of conservatives.'

There's nothing ironic about it. Glass Steagall is no more a republican idea than a woman's right to choose. At a minimum you need to understand the ideological underpinnings of the group you appear to represent before commenting. Preserving 'a sensible balance that protects the resources of milions' is simply not in the conservative playbook. A totally corrupt and rigged banking system is exaclty what conservatives want. I think the Fox News' meme 'fair and balanced' has corrupted your ability to express a cogent thought.

The Libor scandal strikes at the heart of market capitalism. Libor is used to establish borrowing rates for trillions in commercial borrowing and derivatives transactions. If the setting of Libor has been corrupted, market capitalism has been corrupted.

For over 30 years, American society has put its faith in the market as the ultimate determinant of resource allocation and well-being. That faith is well-placed only if markets are managed with integrity. Sadly, we appear to have entered an era where risk is reduced not through sound management, but rather through chicanery.

Unfortunately, the pendulum toward de-regulation has swung too far. Organized oversight is needed to keep markets honest. I applaud the business, media and other voices in the UK and elsewhere who are calling for an investigation of this scandal, punishment of those involved, and a more effective regulatory regimen to correct the system.

You forgot to mention Herman Cain who, when asked about Higgs Boson particles, couldn't recollect whether he had ever met her.  Also Rick Perry, who immediately volunteered that this was the third ("or maybe the fourth") cabinet department that he would eliminate if elected.

Jobs reports are interesting but confusing.  All the pundits are reading them as if they were tea leaves forcasting the presidential election.  The conventional wisdom seems to be that if the numbers are low the president will loose.  No one seems to be paying any attention to what can be done to stimulate jobs.  The Republicans in the House have buried the president's jobs plan and their candidate is campaigning on the platform that he once made a lot of money for his investors and himself so that makes him qualified to be president.  While everyone is playing politics and focusing on November, the American people who have to pay the rent or mortgage and put food on the table until the election are being ignored.
Laughing out loud, Gail-- many thanks!

fivethirtyD, I'm shocked, SHOCKED I tell you, that this neanderthal would use such language in the presence of a lady of such obvious refinement, and in the town of Hadlyme, CT. no less!
I guess had he said instead, "fecal matter" he would've been over qualified for the job?

Howie
5:30, after that hamster sandwich we shared a few days ago, ant eggs can't be all that bad...

MD and Georgie, I mostly agree with you both, but with caution. Much depression does NOT altogether improve with time, especially major depression. A significant minority of them NEVER go away, and at least half of them will recur in three to five years. In addition, depression may do a great deal of harm before it does go away, to educational progress, social relations, and vocational achievement. Many depressed students never get back on track, even if they feel better. We need to take this thing seriously, whenther meds are indicated or not.

As for meds, yes they must be used with caution and parsimony. But they are clearly effective in a way that transcends the faulty analogy of antibiotics for viruses.

Interestingly, CBT may improve the rate, severity, and time to recurrence. Some promising data are emerging for other therapies as well. Therapy - don't leave depression without it.

Wow - we didn't get the idea that staying comfortably in hospice was an option when a family member recently died from cancer.  Basically, they stabilized her after some surgery and sent her home since "she is able to be cared for at home."  So then we began a three-week ordeal in which two personal care attendants had to be paid out of personal funds, 24-7, because none of us was robust enough to move the 120-lb patient around in bed enough to keep her comfortable, and the personal care workers were also hesitant to have one person doing it.  $20,000 later, she died.  Medicare and her personally-paid medigap policy did pay everything else.  It made me wonder what people with more typical savings levels do - probably just suffer back injuries and other trauma.  As it is, the primary family member in attendance suffered such stress, from the dying person's descent into psychosis, the concerns over inadequate pain relief, the tensions over who was there and wasn't there, and so on, that a heart condition was exacerbated, and a 4 hour open heart surgery kept him away from the funeral.  The notion that the dying process and cancer pain are now "well-managed" is not quite right.  This can still be still a hugely traumatic event for family, even when the person dying is somewhat elderly, resources are plentiful, etc. This is probably as it should be, in some ultimate sense, but nobody should underestimate it.

Obviously, Hospice and Palliative Care have developed since 1986 when Hospice was passed into Medicare Law and since 1991, when the Patient Self Determination Act was passed by the Congress as "public policy" to encourage the elderly to die "more cheaply" outside of Hospitals in their own homes or in Nursing Homes or Assisted Care Facilities.

Unfortunately, dying is still a BIG and frightening IDEA for even the elderly, and many patients feel safer in the hospital than they do at home, and, of course, HOSPICE is still an elective under existing law and elderly patients have a right to be treated in the hospital, unless they waive that right under the Patient Self Determination Act and refuse life-extending/life-saving procedures that they believe will not serve their own interests.

Even if patients are on Hospice Care, they cannot legally be kept out of the Emergency Rooms and the Hospitals. even if they have indicated that they want DNR Code status because, of course, under existing law, the DNR can be rescinded at any time.

If patients feel save in the arms of Hospice and their caretakers feel safe, as well, and resigned to death, patients will die at home. But! there have been many "unhappy" Hospice users and Hospice, of course, has not been the answer to reducing end-of-life costs for the elderly.

This is such a contrast to Michael Wolff's story "Mom! I love you" in the New York Magazine which presents a brutal image of end-of-life pain for his Mom, who was suffering from dementia, and the pain and "guilt" he felt and the pain his sister and brother felt at losing the "essence" of their beloved Mother after they permitted her to have a heart operation that was recommened by her heart doctor. .

I was lucky. My Mom lived with my husband and me from the time she was 93 until she was 104-l/2. She only lost some of her cognitive ability after 102. We three were actually pretty healthy and happy in our old age. My Mom had taken care of her Dad until he was 101 ---he died of pneumonia and was never senile. Good Genes Help!

My late husband lived until he was 91 (we were married 60 years) and was always competent but was only hospitalized longer than overnight in the last nine months of his life when he was hospitalized three times because the oncologists were treating him with radiation even though he had Stage IV Supraglottic Cancer, Dysphagia, Aspiration Pneumonia, and abnormal blood chemistry ---and possibly lung cancer. I miss him so much!

"Paula seems to have an unusually large amount of blood."

"Paula's surgeon cannot complete the operation but is too stubborn to hand it over to the resident."

"Paula seems to be doing OK, but her blood pressure is a little low. The anesthesiologist is sure to do something about that right after he finishes his crossword puzzle."

The sugar pusher (oops, I mean concessionaire) should be willing to sell you a refill in your 16 oz cup, charging you the same as if you bought one 32 oz cup. You are using the same cup, so the only extra cost is the labor to refill the cup (OK, charge 10 cents for that.) So nothing really changes: sugar addicts can get their fix, they just need to wait on line again to get the other half.

I can't decide who's the bigger idiot here: the mayor, the soda companies or the movie exhibitors.  If a patron isn't able to purchase a maxi-sized bucket of sugar (oops, I mean "beverage") he/she can just as easily puchase two smaller-sized ones.  Or three or four.  I'm sure the theaters can somehow come up with smaller cups.  Jeez...

In researching caregivers of the elderly, I was surprised to learn that the top 6 diagnoses of those receiving care are all neurological problems, comprising 57% of all those receiving care (see reference #1)
For those interested in more extensive recent surveys of caregivers of the elderly, two good sources are:
1.) 2011 NFCA/Allsup Family Caregiver Survey and National Alliance for Caregiving. www.allsup.com/Portals/4/NFCA-Caregiver-Survey10.11.pdf
2.) Caregiving in the U.S.: A focused look at those caring for someone age 50 or older. www.caregiving.org

And no one wants to toss you, XWJ.
@Deadline---Thanks. If true, it's a testament to the tolerance of the Wordplay crowd.

I was surprised to solve it at all after my first pass. Finished in 42 minutes, which was s good Saturday.

Mac

Spent about 30 minutes fiddling with units, trying to figure out what a Newton per ampere-meter might be. Decided it was probably simpler to start the puzzle than try to remember what I once knew about electricity and magnetism.

It took me 90 minutes, but to my amazement I solved this correctly. Am very impressed by those who can solve a puzzle like this one in less than 30 minutes.

Wasn't familiar with KNOWSONESONIONS, ISTLE, WUSHU, ANTEGG, IGY, GABLER or ERNANI, but somehow I figured them out.

Too tired to add anything more.

I see I wrote KNOW MY ONIONS.  That just shows you I really don't know KNOWS ONES ONIONS.  Amy Reynaldo is the guest blogger for Rex today.  Now if you realy want to see a critical comment with a deft humurous hand, it's an instant classic.

I don't know my onions, but I remembered KNOWSONESONIONS once I had a few crosses.

We eat our share of Vidalia onions and they are very good. The Georgia legislature passed a law back in the 80's restricting use of the name Vidalia to those grown in a very precise area.

Vidalia is very... rural. The largest employer is the nearby state prison. My wife interviewed for a job there after she finished her residency and I drove down with her. The job offered a very good salary and would also have given her breaks on her student loans because it is a rural, somewhat underserved area. Financially, it would have been great.

We had driven around the town a bit before the interview. My wife is a city girl. After the interview we got in the car and she just sat there looking straight ahead. I looked at her for a minute and finally said, "I really don't want to live down here." I believe she exhaled at that point.
Clarification after reading my own text. My wife interviewed for a job in Vidalia, but not at the state prison.

Interesting.  I know my vadalias from my reds but I don't know I KNOW MY ONIONS.  So I'm with Deb on this one.  I think the Teflon Don lost his title once he spent the rest of his life in federal prison.  Sometimes the obscurities of a themeless puzzle allows for the kind of freedom to construct that constricts my solving experience.  Is that tactful enough Deb?
Tell that to universities that are acquiring patents faster than you can say Higgs boson.

The thing got built under  the mountains of Switzerland, Fraance and Italy, but no country has control of science.  Scientist from countries all over the world,  theoretical and particle pysicists, contributed papers, met together for long periods in various spots. No country owns or controls science. It knows no boundries. American phyysicists contributed to the project as much as any other country.

Of course, you're kidding, afterall, you ARE "The Lasz!"

If you remember Len, can one say you're Deighton yourself?

LONDON swings like a pantaloon should...:-)

Howie

great puzzle, tim, thanks, and a most appropriate interjection. hardly a rap thing, indeed.
but he "sang" with them.(sorry...can't hep it!).
although i got to mhp, i was still trying to figure out what "the tef london" meant til i read the blog...duh!
JoJo,, I can only give you the highest compliment:  Your posting could have been written by Gail Collins.
Rod Serling, come back. All is forgiven.
Oh, and Michelle Bachmann is writing witty columns in that European parallel universe.

Gail, I take strong exception to your implication that the U.S. has fallen behind in science. Our creationist museum in Kentucky is the only one of its kind in the world!

By the way, the Europeon scientists have actually discovered one of these parallel universes. This one is almost identical to ours, except by a random fluctuation, their U.S. Supreme Court did not stop their counterpart to Al Gore from winning the presidency in 2000. They have now expanded Clinton's federal surplus, have stopped global warming, have cured all major diseases via stem cell research, and have reached a golden age of ongoing peace, enlightenment, scientific progress, and prosperity across the whole planet.

Oh, and Mitt Romney has become President of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

No gravity?!
Gravity is the fourth dimension.
Levity is the fifth.
I am sure that in the Hollywood movie about this event, the heroic scientist will be played by a grey-haired Tom Cruise.

As a retired scientists I should not be laughing on Collins's take on the formidable boson made, apparently, from an odorless molasses. Or kind of related to it. Or whatever.

I think I know (at the age of 78) that there is actually no gravity, only warping of time/space caused by mass. Newton thought (although he was unable to explain it) that there was this mysterious long distance force that keept our solar system (at his time nobody knew anything about galaxies) together - with that central force, one can instantly get Kepler laws. That actually was a good approximation for almost everything except a slightyly annoying behavior or Mercury, too close to the gigantic mass of Sun.

So, Einstein explained it - no more mysterious long distance force, just a slight warping of time/spae. Since then we kind of discovered (another very peculiar discovery) that black holes can actually distort the time space to the point that time stops.

OK, we can handle that today. Higgs boson (I like to call it Higgs bussom) we cannot. The best we can say about it is what Collins so perceptively wrote. The first thing is, of course, that regadless of its discovery by godless Europeans, it is OUR particle since we have discovered virtually everything else. That make this buissom close to all of ujs. Thanks, Ms. Collins.

The Republicans, whose Congressional representatives won't pass a single one of the President's job-creation proposals, are obviously enjoying the static unemployment figures.  Notice, however, that they're no longer blaming Mr. Obama for the spike in oil prices.  With petrol costs having declined over these last few months, you'd think that the President would be entitled to some of the credit. That, however, would entail removing the target from his back and it's clear that no member of the GOP can be bothered to make the effort.
Not if Newt 'the Moon's Mayor' Gingrich has anything to say about.

The U.S. is falling further behind the Europeans and the Chinese. Soon the Chinese will be on the moon and claim it for the Peoples Republic of China. That is not a problem for Republicans who just don't get the science thing, they are still baffled by Darwin who died 130 years ago. What might annoy the Republicans, is that by the time they figure out there is a moon to be exploited, all the fast food restaurants up there will already be controlled by the Chinese.

Lasz is right, fivethirty, nothing more popular on diner menus all across the USA, than HAMster and antEGGS!

Howie
I'm more used to "knows one's scallions."
